Title.evidence: The BREAST trial was a randomized clinical trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The BREAST trial was a randomized clinical trial conducted between November 2, 2015, and October 31, 2021, performed in 7 hospitals across the Netherlands.

Participants.evidence: The patients with breast cancer who had undergone mastectomy and were seeking breast reconstruction were screened for eligibility (radiotherapy history and physique) by participating plastic surgeons.

Intervention.evidence: Interventions: Breast reconstruction with AFT plus expansion or 2-phased IBR.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To investigate quality of life (QoL) among patients undergoing a new breast reconstruction technique, autologous fat transfer (AFT), compared with that among patients undergoing implant-based reconstruction (IBR).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The predefined primary outcome was QoL at 12 months after final surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was done in a 1:1 ratio.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 193 female patients (mean [SD] age, 49.2 [10.6] years) 18 years or older who desired breast reconstruction were included.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In total, 64 women in the AFT group and 68 women in the IBR group completed follow-up.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The BREAST-Q scores were higher in the AFT group in all 5 domains and significantly higher in 3: satisfaction with breasts (difference, 9.9; P = .002), physical well-being: chest (difference; 7.6; P = .007), and satisfaction with outcome (difference, 7.6; P = .04).

Harms.evidence: No differences in oncological serious adverse events were found.
